headline: Stocks to Watch Recap: Lowe’s, Toll Brothers, Estée Lauder, Intel
summary: ↗️ Lowe's (LOW): The home-improvement retailer boosted its annual outlook, fueling a modest 0.3% gain in its stock. Lowe's agreed to buy distributor Foundation Building Materials for $8.8 billion. ↘️Intel (INTC): The chip maker's stock lost 7%, erasing gains from Tuesday that followed SoftBank's agreement to invest in the company.

content.title: Stocks to Watch Recap: Lowe’s, Toll Brothers, Estée Lauder, Intel
content.summary: ↗️ Lowe's (LOW): The home-improvement retailer boosted its annual outlook, fueling a modest 0.3% gain in its stock. Lowe's agreed to buy distributor Foundation Building Materials for $8.8 billion. ↘️Intel (INTC): The chip maker's stock lost 7%, erasing gains from Tuesday that followed SoftBank's agreement to invest in the company.

headline: Estée Lauder Stock Drops After Beauty Company Reports Steep Operating Loss
summary: Estée Lauder shares fell after the company reported a 12% drop in sales and a doubling of its operating loss for last quarter. The maker of Clinique and M.A.C. cosmetics said subdued consumer confidence in North America had led some retailers to tighten their inventory.

headline: How Louis Vuitton's new $160 lipstick is a 'strategic play'

headline: Why Estée Lauder (EL) Shares Are Trading Lower Today
summary: Shares of beauty products company Estée Lauder (NYSE:EL) fell 4.9% in the afternoon session after the company reported a sharp decline in sales for its fourth quarter and provided a weaker-than-expected forecast for the upcoming fiscal year. Revenue for the quarter fell 11.9% year on year to $3.41 billion, meeting Wall Street’s expectations. However, other key metrics disappointed investors. While adjusted earnings of $0.09 per share met analyst estimates, it marked a significant drop from $0.64

headline: Estee Lauder Outlook Disappoints as Losses Widen
summary: Estee Lauder  widened its loss in its fiscal fourth quarter as sales continued to struggle, and it issued a dismal full-year outlook.  The beauty company behind MAC, Smashbox and Jo Malone, said Wednesday that costs tied to tariffs are projected to ding earnings by $100 million in its current fiscal year.  Estee Lauder added it will try to offset “more than half” of the levies by leveraging trade programs and optimizing its supply chain.

content.title: Estee Lauder Outlook Disappoints as Losses Widen
content.summary: Estee Lauder  widened its loss in its fiscal fourth quarter as sales continued to struggle, and it issued a dismal full-year outlook.  The beauty company behind MAC, Smashbox and Jo Malone, said Wednesday that costs tied to tariffs are projected to ding earnings by $100 million in its current fiscal year.  Estee Lauder added it will try to offset “more than half” of the levies by leveraging trade programs and optimizing its supply chain.

headline: Your Cosmetics To Get Expensive As Estée Lauder Anticipates $100 Million In Tariffs
summary: Estée Lauder Companies, Inc. (NYSE:EL) shares plummeted in the premarket session on Wednesday after the company reported fourth-quarter results. The company reported adjusted earnings per share of 9 cents, which is in line with the street view. Quarterly sales of $3.41 billion (down 12% year over year) outpaced the analyst consensus estimate of $3.397 billion. headline: Estee Lauder stock dips after cutting profit outlook on weak demand, tariffs
summary: Investing.com -- Estee Lauder (NYSE:EL) saw its shares slide more than 4% on Wednesday after the cosmetics giant forecast annual profit below Wall Street expectations on Wednesday, citing ongoing weakness in demand in the U.S. and China as well as tariff uncertainty.

content.title: Estee Lauder stock dips after cutting profit outlook on weak demand, tariffs
content.summary: Investing.com -- Estee Lauder (NYSE:EL) saw its shares slide more than 4% on Wednesday after the cosmetics giant forecast annual profit below Wall Street expectations on Wednesday, citing ongoing weakness in demand in the U.S. and China as well as tariff uncertainty.

headline: Estée Lauder (NYSE:EL) Posts Q2 Sales In Line With Estimates But Stock Drops 10.5%
summary: Beauty products company Estée Lauder (NYSE:EL) met Wall Street’s revenue expectations in Q2 CY2025, but sales fell by 11.9% year on year to $3.41 billion. Its non-GAAP profit of $0.09 per share was in line with analysts’ consensus estimates.

content.title: Estée Lauder (NYSE:EL) Posts Q2 Sales In Line With Estimates But Stock Drops 10.5%
content.summary: Beauty products company Estée Lauder (NYSE:EL) met Wall Street’s revenue expectations in Q2 CY2025, but sales fell by 11.9% year on year to $3.41 billion. Its non-GAAP profit of $0.09 per share was in line with analysts’ consensus estimates.

headline: Estee Lauder: Fiscal Q4 Earnings Snapshot
summary: The average estimate of 11 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research was for earnings of 8 cents per share. The beauty products company posted revenue of $3.41 billion in the period, also exceeding Street forecasts. Nine analysts surveyed by Zacks expected $3.4 billion.

content.title: Estee Lauder: Fiscal Q4 Earnings Snapshot
content.summary: The average estimate of 11 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research was for earnings of 8 cents per share. The beauty products company posted revenue of $3.41 billion in the period, also exceeding Street forecasts. Nine analysts surveyed by Zacks expected $3.4 billion.

headline: Estee Lauder forecasts profit below estimates, warns of $100 million tariff hit
summary: (Reuters) -Estee Lauder said on Wednesday it would cut inventory and promotions to help mitigate rising costs, after the luxury cosmetic maker warned that a $100 million hit from tariffs would weigh on its annual profit forecast.  The company's shares fell about 4% in afternoon trading after Estee Lauder also forecast annual profit below estimates.  Higher costs related to the Trump administration's unpredictable trade policies have dampened consumer spending, hurting businesses, especially higher-end brands like Estee Lauder and Tapestry as the luxury sector struggles with sagging demand.

Higher costs related to the Trump administration's unpredictable trade policies have dampened consumer spending, hurting businesses, especially higher-end brands like Estee Lauder and Tapestry as the luxury sector struggles with sagging demand.
